Questions: How do you write a single-line comment
Answers: Using //

Questions: What does the % (modulus) operator do
Answers: It returns the remainder of a division.

Questions: Which operator is used to concatenate strings
Answers: The + operator

Questions: What method converts a string to uppercase
Answers: .toUpperCase()

Questions: Which function displays a message in a popup window
Answers: alert()

Questions: Which array method removes the last element
Answers: .pop()

Questions: What symbol is used for logical AND
Can you redeclare a let variable in the same scope
Answers: No

Questions: Which event occurs when a user clicks an HTML element
Answers: onclick

Questions: How do you create a new Date object
Answers: new Date()

Questions: How do you join two arrays
Answers: Using the .concat() method

Questions: How do you check if a number is even
What keyword stops a loop from executing
Answers: break

Questions: What keyword skips the current iteration of a loop
Answers: continue

Questions: How do you remove whitespace from both ends of a string
Answers: Using .trim()

Questions: What is the global object in client-side JavaScript
Answers: window

Questions: What is the data type of true
Answers: Boolean

Questions: How do you check the length of a string str
Answers: str.length

Questions: How do you define a function named myFunc
Answers: function myFunc() {  }

Questions: How do you select an element by its ID
Answers: document.getElementById('idName')

Questions: What is Event Bubbling
Answers: When an event happens on an element, it first runs the handlers on it, then on its parent, then all the way up on other ancestors

Questions: What is the difference between window and document
Answers: window is the global object representing the browser tab; document is a property of window representing the loaded HTML content

Questions: How do default parameters work in ES6
Answers: You can initialize named parameters with default values if no value or undefined is passed

Questions: What is Array Destructuring
Answers: A syntax to unpack values from arrays into distinct variables

Questions: What is the difference between setTimeout and setInterval
Answers: setTimeout runs once after a delay; setInterval runs repeatedly at specified intervals

Questions: What is an IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression)
Answers: A function that runs as soon as it is defined

Questions: How do you check if a specific key exists in an object
Answers: Using the in operator (e.g., "key" in obj)

Questions: What is the difference between array.forEach() and array.map()
Answers: map returns a new array; forEach executes a function for side effects and returns undefined

Questions: What is the Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ)
Answers: The time between entering a scope and the actual declaration of a let or const variable, during which accessing it throws an error

Questions: How do you create a Promise
Answers: new Promise((resolve, reject) => {  })

Questions: What keywords are used to handle errors in JavaScript
Answers: try, catch, finally, and throw

Questions: What is a module in JavaScript
Answers: A file containing code that can export portions of itself (export) and import code from other files (import)

Questions: How do you clone an object (shallow copy) using ES6
Answers: Using the spread operator: const copy = { ...original };

Questions: What is the purpose of the class keyword
Answers: It provides a cleaner syntax to create objects

Questions: How do you inherit from a class
Answers: Using the extends keyword

Questions: What is localStorage limit usually
Answers: Approximately 5MB per domain

Questions: Does const make an object immutable
Answers: No, it prevents reassignment of the variable identifier, but the properties of the object can still be changed

Questions: What is the arguments object
Answers: An array-like object accessible inside functions (except arrow functions) that contains the values of the arguments passed

Questions: What is the difference between null and undefined in terms of usage
Answers: undefined is the default value of uninitialized variables; null is a value explicitly assigned to indicate "no value"

Questions: How does JSON.parse() work
Answers: It converts a JSON string into a JavaScript object

Questions: Explain the Event Loop
Answers: A mechanism that handles asynchronous callbacks. It constantly checks if the Call Stack is empty; if so, it pushes tasks from the Callback Queue/Microtask Queue to the stack

Questions: What is the difference between Microtasks and Macrotasks
Answers: Microtasks (Promises, queueMicrotask) have higher priority and run immediately after the current script; Macrotasks (setTimeout, I/O) run in the next loop iteration

Questions: What is a Closure Memory Leak
Answers: When a closure holds a reference to a large variable in an outer scope, preventing the Garbage Collector from freeing that memory even if it's no longer needed

Questions: Explain Prototypal Inheritance vs. Classical Inheritance
Answers: Classical inheritance uses classes as blueprints. Prototypal inheritance uses objects linked to other objects (via the prototype chain) to share properties.

Questions: What is the difference between __proto__ and prototype
Answers: prototype is a property of constructor functions used to build __proto__; __proto__ is the actual reference on an instance object pointing to its prototype

Questions: How does the new keyword work internally
Answers: It creates a new object, links its prototype to the constructor's prototype, binds this to the new object, and returns the object

Questions: What is the difference between Promise.all() and Promise.allSettled()
Answers: all() rejects immediately if one promise fails; allSettled() waits for all to finish regardless of success or failure

Questions: What is a WeakMap
Answers: A collection of key/value pairs where keys must be objects and are "weakly" held

Questions: What is a Proxy object
Answers: An object that wraps another object and intercepts operations (like reading/writing properties) allowing custom behavior

Questions: What is Debouncing
Answers: A technique to ensure a function is not called too frequently; it waits for a pause in invocations before running

Questions: What is Throttling
Answers: A technique to ensure a function is called at most once in a specified time period

Questions: What is the purpose of Symbol primitive
Answers: To create unique identifiers, often used for object property keys to avoid name collisions

Questions: How does JavaScript handle integers larger than 2^53 - 1
Answers: Using the BigInt data type

Questions: What is the Critical Rendering Path
Answers: The sequence of steps the browser takes to convert HTML, CSS, and JS into actual pixels on the screen

Questions: What is a Service Worker
Answers: A script that runs in the background, separate from the web page, enabling features like offline caching and push notifications

Questions: What is a Polyfill
Answers: What is a Polyfill

Questions: What is "Hoisting" regarding classes
Answers: Unlike functions, classes are not hoisted (or rather, they are in the TDZ) and cannot be used before declaration

Questions: What is Tail Call Optimization (TCO)
Answers: An optimization where the engine reuses the stack frame for the last function call in a function to prevent stack overflow in recursion (supported in strict mode in some engines)

Questions: What is a Memory Leak and how do you detect it
Answers: Unwanted memory retention; detected using Chrome DevTools "Memory" tab (Heap Snapshots)

Questions: What is the Shadow DOM
Answers: A way to attach a hidden, separate DOM tree to an element, providing encapsulation for CSS and JS (used in Web Components)
